The awaited-for ruling by the Supreme Court, another 5-4 decision.
 
 http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20050627/ap_on_go_su_co/scotus_ten_commandments_4
 
 "When the government acts with the ostensible and predominant purpose of advancing religion, it violates tha central Establishment clause value of official religious neutrality," he [Souter] said.
 
 Right on!

Hmmmm, I'm a bit split on this whole issue. A part of me feels that religious symbols should be banned from government property, but that is because they tend to be dominated by Christian symbols, and so it gives a very lopsided view. On the other hand, I once wrote a paper for a civics course defending them in which I said that symbology frm all kinds of different relgions and philosophies sould be put on goernment prperty to show their impact on society.

Here is a relevant article to the thread. Amazing what the court allows and doesn't allow to be funded and sponsored by our government:
 
 http://www.townhall.com/columnists/anncoulter/ac20050629.shtml
